anchor.surface_text: On both these points the Trial Court found the plaintiffs case proved and rejected the defence pleas.

facts.text: Sadagopa was a Shudra (admitted)

anchor.surface_text: and that even if Padmavathi belonged to the Brahmin caste and no to the caste to which Sadagopa belonged the marriage is valid under the existing law. The validity of the Act itself appears to have been challenged before the Trial Court, but, this was rejected.

facts.text: High Court agreed with Trial Court that Padmavathi and Sadagopa duly married and plaintiff born of that marriage

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the defendants, the High Court of Judicature at Madras agreed with the Trial Court that Padmavathi and Sadagopa had been duly married and that the plaintiff Bhakthavathasalam was the issue of that marriage,

facts.text: High Court opinion: Padmavathi was a Shudra, same as Sadagopa

anchor.surface_text: being born of Padmavathi to Sadagopa. The High Court was however of opinion that Padmavathi was a Shudra, the same as Sadagopa.

facts.text: High Court: even assuming Padmavathi Brahmin, marriage validated by Hindu Marriages Validity Act, 1949

anchor.surface_text: Assuming however for arguments sake that Padmavathi was a Brahmin the High Court agreed with the Trial Court that the marriage was validated by the Hindu Marriages Validity Act, 1949,

anchor.surface_text: and so, the plaintiff would have all the rights of legitimate son vis-a-vis the coparcenary to which his father belonged.

facts.text: Validity of Act unsuccessfully challenged in High Court

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the Act was unsuccessfully challenged. Accordingly,

facts.text: High Court affirmed Trial Court judgment and decree, dismissed appeal

anchor.surface_text: the High Court affirmed the judgment and decree passed by the Trial Court and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Present appeal filed by defendants (appellants) with special leave against High Court decision

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision of the High Court the present appeal has been filed by the defendants with special leave.

facts.text: Appellants attacked findings on marriage and paternity, but Supreme Court found no misreading of evidence

anchor.surface_text: In support of the appeal, Mr. Pathak tried first to attack the concurrent findings of facts of the courts below as regards the marriage between Sadagopa and Padmavathi and the fact of the plaintiff being born of Padmavathi to Sadagopa in that marriage.

facts.text: Supreme Court held plaintiff legitimate son of Sadagopa despite contentions, marriage valid under Hindu Marriages Validity Act, 1949

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore come to the conclusion that even if the Trial Court was right in thinking that Padmavathi was a Brahmin girl and no a Shudra, the position in law was, as found by the courts below, viz., it was a valid Hindu marriage and Bhakthavathasalam a legitimate son of Sadagopa

facts.text: Plaintiff has rights of coparcener in joint family properties

anchor.surface_text: with all the rights of a coparcener in regard to the joint family properties and other matters.

facts.text: Hindu Marriages Validity Act, 1949 retrospectively validates marriages between different castes

anchor.surface_text: The relevant provisions of the Act is in s. 3 and is in these words- Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force or in any text, or interpretation of Hindu law, or in any custom or usage, no marriage between Hindus shall be deemed to be invalid or ever to have been invalid by reason only of the fact that the parties thereto belonged to different religions, castes, sub-castes or sects.

facts.text: No other point urged in appeal

anchor.surface_text: No other point was urged in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court was of opinion that Padmavathi was a Brahmin, and as admittedly Sadagopa was a Shudra, the marriage would be invalid according to the Hindu Law as it stood before the Hindu Marriages Validity Act, 1949. It held however that the position had been entirely changed by section 3 of this Act and that even if Padmavathi belonged to the Brahmin caste and number to the caste to which Sadagopa belonged the marriage is valid under the existing law.

arguments.claim: Concurrent findings on marriage and paternity vitiated by misreading of evidence

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision of the High Court the present appeal has been filed by the defendants with special leave. In support of the appeal, Mr. Pathak tried first to attack the concurrent findings of facts of the courts below as regards the marriage between Sadagopa and Padmavathi and the fact of the plaintiff being born of Padmavathi to Sadagopa in that marriage.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: dismissed the appeal. Against this decision of the High Court the present appeal has been filed by the defendants with special leave. In support of t

arguments.court_reasoning: No misreading or error pointed out to justify re-assessment

arguments.claim: Hindu Marriages Validity Act, 1949 only validates marriage but does not confer legitimacy on child born before the Act from previously invalid marriage

anchor.surface_text: Having failed in this attempt Mr Pathak contended that as a matter of law the plaintiff did not become a legitimate son of Sadagopa inspite of the provisions of the Hindu Marriages Validity Act, 1949. According to the learned counsel the only effect of this Act is that the marriage becomes valid and it has no effect as regards the legitimacy of the child born before the date of the Act. The relevant provisions of the Act is in s. 3 and is in these words- Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force or in any text, or interpretation of Hindu law, or in any custom or usage, no marriage between Hindus shall be deemed to be invalid or ever to have been invalid by reason only of the fact that the parties thereto belonged to different religions, castes, sub-castes or sects.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: opinion, the use of the words the issue of numbersuch marriage shall be illegitimate was number really necessary in s. 1 of the Hindu Widows Re-Marri

arguments.court_reasoning: Misconceived; Act retrospective, validates past marriages and legitimizes issue

arguments.claim: Proper construction of s.3 affects only status of marriage parties, not legitimacy of pre-Act children; express provision needed for legitimacy

anchor.surface_text: For his proposition the learned counsel could not cite any authority and that is natural because the contention raised is entirely misconceived and can be characterised as extravagant. He tried to persuade us however that a proper construction of the words used in the section,justifies the conclusion that it was the status of the parties to the marriage that was only sought to be affected. He conceded that in the case of every marriage celebrated after the date of the Act, the result of the marriage being valid would be, that the children born of the marriage would be legitimate, but argued that the same result would not follow in the case of a marriage which having been celebrated before the date of the Act was invalid at the time and the children were illegiti- mate then.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: opinion, the use of the words the issue of numbersuch marriage shall be illegitimate was number really necessary in s. 1 of the Hindu Widows Re-Marri

arguments.court_reasoning: Object includes legitimizing children; status regularization part but not only

arguments.claim: Absence of express legitimacy clause like in Hindu Widows Re-Marriage Act s.1 shows no intent to legitimize pre-Act children

anchor.surface_text: In support of his arguments he has drawn our attention to the wordings of s. 1 of the Hindu Widows Re-Marriage Act, 1856, which is in these words- No marriage contracted between Hindus shall be invalid, and the issue of such marriage shall be legitimate, by reason of the women having been previously married or betrothed to another person who was dead at the time of such marriage, any custom and any interpretation of Hindu law to the contrary notwithstanding.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: opinion, the use of the words the issue of numbersuch marriage shall be illegitimate was number really necessary in s. 1 of the Hindu Widows Re-Marri

arguments.court_reasoning: Words in 1856 Act mere abundant caution; not necessary as validity implies legitimacy; absence inconsequential

arguments.claim: Hindu Marriages Validity Act s.3 retrospectively validates inter-caste marriages and legitimizes their issue, including pre-Act children

anchor.surface_text: The absence of any phrase similar to the issue of such marriage shall be legitimate in the Hindu Marriages Validity Act, 1949, is claimed by the learned counsel to support his contention. We cannot agree. In our opinion, the use of the words the issue of such marriage shall be legitimate was not really necessary in s. 1 of the Hindu Widows Re-Marriage Act, and even without these words the effect of a marriage being valid would necessarily have been that the, issue of the marriage was legitimate.

holdings.text: The concurrent findings of fact by the courts below regarding the marriage between Sadagopa and Padmavathi and the paternity of Bhakthavathsalam are upheld as no misreading of evidence or other error justifying re-assessment was shown.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel wanted to say that the findings of the High Court on these points were vitiated by misreading of important items of evidence. He could not however point out any such misreading nor any other error to justify our re-assessment of the evidence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant counsel failed to demonstrate any misreading of evidence or error warranting interference under special leave appeal.

holdings.text: Section 3 of the Hindu Marriages Validity Act, 1949 operates retrospectively to validate Hindu marriages between parties of different castes, sub-castes or sects that occurred before the Act, rendering them never to have been invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant provisions of the Act is in s. 3 and is in these words- Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force or in any text, or interpretation of Hindu law, or in any custom or usage, no marriage between Hindus shall be deemed to be invalid or ever to have been invalid by reason only of the fact that the parties thereto belonged to different religions, castes, sub-castes or sects. [...] The Act was however in terms retrospective and validated marriages that had taken place before the Act between parties belonging to different castes, sub-castes and sects.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'or ever to have been invalid' expressly provides retrospective validation overriding prior Hindu law.

holdings.text: Retrospective validation of a marriage under section 3 of the Hindu Marriages Validity Act, 1949 necessarily legitimizes children born of that marriage prior to the Act, without need for express provision on legitimacy.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the use of the words the issue of such marriage shall be legitimate was not really necessary in s. 1 of the Hindu Widows Re-Marriage Act, and even without these words the effect of a marriage being valid would necessarily have been that the issue of the marriage was legitimate. These words were put in the section by the legislature in 1856 as a matter of abundant caution. The absence of such words in the Hindu Marriages Validity Act, 1949 is of no consequence. [...] It is idle to contend that the object of the legislature was only to regularise the status of the husband and the wife. [...] But equally important, or perhaps more important object was that the children of the marriages would become legitimate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical consequence of marriage validity is child legitimacy; express words in 1856 Act were abundant caution only; legislative object includes legitimizing issue of past inter-caste marriages.

holdings.text: The marriage between Padmavathi and Sadagopa is valid under section 3 of the Hindu Marriages Validity Act, 1949 even assuming Padmavathi was Brahmin and Sadagopa Shudra, making Bhakthavathsalam their legitimate son entitled to coparcenary rights in the joint family.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore come to the conclusion that even if the Trial Court was right in thinking that Padmavathi was a Brahmin girl and not a Shudra, the position in law was, as found by the courts below, viz., it was a valid Hindu marriage and Bhakthavathasalam a legitimate son of Sadagopa with all the rights of a coparcener in regard to the joint family properties and other matters.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of Act's retrospective validation and consequent legitimacy to facts, affirming lower courts' position even on assumed caste difference.

justification_sets.label: Section 3, Hindu Marriages Validity Act, 1949 support

outcome.relief_summary: Lower courts' findings affirmed; marriage held valid under Hindu Marriages Validity Act, 1949; plaintiff held legitimate son with coparcenary rights including 1/8th share in partition

anchor.surface_text: The relevant provisions of the Act is in s. 3 and is in these words- Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force or in any text, or interpretation of Hindu law, or in any custom or usage, no marriage between Hindus shall be deemed to be invalid or ever to have been invalid by reason only of the fact that the parties thereto belonged to different religions, castes, sub-castes or sects. [...] The Act was however in terms retrospective and validated marriages that had taken place before the Act between parties belonging to different castes, sub-castes and sects.

[...] The Act was however in terms retrospective and validated marriages that had taken place before the Act between parties belonging to different castes, sub-castes and sects.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the use of the words the issue of such marriage shall be legitimate was not really necessary in s. 1 of the Hindu Widows Re-Marriage Act, and even without these words the effect of a marriage being valid would necessarily have been that the issue of the marriage was legitimate. These words were put in the section by the legislature in 1856 as a matter of abundant caution. The absence of such words in the Hindu Marriages Validity Act, 1949 is of no consequence. [...] It is idle to contend that the object of the legislature was only to regularise the status of the husband and the wife. [...] But equally important, or perhaps more important object was that the children of the marriages would become legitimate.

In our opinion, the use of the words the issue of such marriage shall be legitimate was not really necessary in s. 1 of the Hindu Widows Re-Marriage Act, and even without these words the effect of a marriage being valid would necessarily have been that the issue of the marriage was legitimate. anchor.surface_text: We have therefore come to the conclusion that even if the Trial Court was right in thinking that Padmavathi was a Brahmin girl and not a Shudra, the position in law was, as found by the courts below, viz., it was a valid Hindu marriage and Bhakthavathasalam a legitimate son of Sadagopa with all the rights of a coparcener in regard to the joint family properties and other matters.

We have therefore come to the conclusion that even if the Trial Court was right in thinking that Padmavathi was a Brahmin girl and not a Shudra, the position in law was, as found by the courts below, viz., it was a valid Hindu marriage and Bhakthavathasalam a legitimate son of Sadagopa with all the rights of a coparcener in regard to the joint family properties and other matters.
